OLD MILL TOWN
Investigating the history of Hiroo

NBUTSU

The Shibuya River starts at Shinjuku Gyoen. Running southward, it 
=
makes a big horseshoe curve near Ebisu and heads north to Roppongi. 
At Ich=
i-no-hashi, it abruptly bends east to eventually pour into 
Tokyo Bay. The =
river's upper reaches are now culverts, but water

ibuya Station in a concrete conduit. In its 
lower reaches the river (menti=
oned in this column Oct. 7, 2005) has

Along=
 the middle reaches -- in the Harajuku, Shibuya and Hiroo 
areas -- the wat=
ers used to be abundant and were used to run mills, 
a crucial source of po=
wer in preindustrialized Japan. In this region

ity to the east and farming villages to

 grinding grain into flour or in

just about everyone ate

y, preparing kome

eel at its bottom. Afterward, the

d building, the 7-meter-in-diameter mill turned out hefty

As of 1888, 34 mi=
lls existed along the Shibuya River, and they were

entury when electricity was

ku, founded in 1879 by local volunteers. 

In the wake of the 1868 Meiji=
 Restoration, enthusiasm ran high among

odern school systems. The decree

 1872, but with its

her reasons,

f Tokyo. The first elementary school in Shibuya-ku was built in

 Store until the

awa Kinzaburo's own involvement in Rinsen Elementary School is

ight. To reach its

d by Lord

father, Kuroda Nagamasa (1568-1623), who had contributed greatly to
